sn22.22:1.2: “Mendicants, I will teach you the burden, the bearer of the burden, the taking up of the burden, and the putting down of the burden.
sn22.22:1.5: The five grasping aggregates, it should be said.
sn22.22:1.7: The grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn22.22:2.1: And who is the bearer of the burden?
sn22.22:2.2: The individual, it should be said;
sn22.22:2.3: the venerable of such and such name and clan.
sn22.22:2.4: This is called the bearer of the burden.
sn22.22:3.1: And what is the taking up of the burden?
sn22.22:3.2: It’s the craving that leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure wherever it lands. That is,
sn22.22:3.3: craving for sensual pleasures, craving for existence, and craving for nonexistence.
sn22.22:3.4: This is called the taking up of the burden.
sn22.22:4.1: And what is the putting down of the burden?
sn22.22:4.2: It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not clinging to it.
sn22.22:4.3: This is called the putting down of the burden.”
sn22.22:5.1: That is what the Buddha said.
sn22.22:5.2: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
sn22.22:6.2: and the individual is the bearer of the burden.
sn22.22:6.3: Taking up the burden is suffering in the world,
sn22.22:6.4: and putting the burden down is happiness.
sn22.22:7.1: When the heavy burden is put down
sn22.22:7.3: one who has plucked out craving, root and all,
